properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of freezing rain are expected to end by midnight tonight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-21T08:59:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-20T19:51:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2510643400.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Snow will begin falling early this evening. The highest accumulations and lowest visibilities in falling snow are expected to occur overnight before the snowfall lightens and begins to taper off Tuesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-21T03:24:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-20T11:25:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0281160087.2020
Area: Hay River Region including Enterprise, Thebacha Region including Ft. Smith - Salt River Reserve, Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Snow, at times heavy, will begin late this afternoon and end by Tuesday afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-21T09:28:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-20T17:29:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1542085965.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A slow moving Pacific frontal system will continue to give snow over the Williston region and Pine Pass this morning. 15 to 25 cm of snow has accumulated form the current storm and another 5 cm is possible this morning The snow will finally ease this afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-20T21:59:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-20T12:30:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2449347429.2020
Area: Williston
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. A bitterly cold airmass remains entrenched over the central Arctic. Air temperatures approaching -40C combined with wind speeds up to 15 km/h will produce wind chill values below -55 tonight. LIttle relief is expected on Tuesday, however increasing cloud cover on Tuesday night into Wednesday will provide some improvement. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-21T12:19:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-20T20:20:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2672242220.2020
Area: Hall Beach
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A slow moving Pacific frontal system will continue to give snow over the Williston region and Pine Pass this morning. 15 to 25 cm of snow has accumulated form the current storm and another 5 cm is possible this morning The snow will finally ease this afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-20T21:59:00-00:00

Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific frontal system will remain stationary over the north coast this morning. Consequently, heavy snow will continue this morning. Total snowfall accumulations of up to 50 cm are expected. In addition, there is a risk of freezing rain as warmer air moves in aloft. The snow mixed with freezing rain will finally end near noon as the front moves to the east. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-21T03:01:09-00:00
